summary: This 1934 West Africa Court of Appeal decision involved a land dispute between Kwamina Kuma (plaintiff-respondent) and Kofi Kuma (defendant-appellant) over a parcel known as Tenkyirem. The plaintiff sought a declaration of title and an injunction but failed to provide sufficient evidence to meet the burden of proof. The court held that the plaintiff should have been non-suited at trial due to inadequate proof of ownership. The defendant successfully demonstrated continuous, unchallenged occupation of the land for six generations through ancestral lineage from Kweku Andoh, a sub-captain of the Abura tribe. The plaintiff's claims of ownership, including alleged permissions granted to others and interference with a land sale, were deemed unconvincing. The appeal was allowed, the lower court's judgment reversed, and a judgment of non-suit entered in favor of the defendant with costs.
rationaleHighlights: Plaintiff failed to discharge burden of proof for declaration of title
Defendant proved six generations of uninterrupted possession
Plaintiff's evidence on acts of ownership was vague and uncorroborated
No demarcation of farms on disputed land plan
Defendant's ancestors never paid tribute or 'drink' to plaintiff
Prior abortive litigation in Abakrampa Tribunal did not establish plaintiff's title
Clearance of land by Kweku Andoh established Abura lineage and possession
Court found lower judge erred in not non-suiting plaintiff
